The smallest building blocks for modern, accessible web interfaces  CSS-first, zero runtime, three ways to consume.
The smallest building blocks for modern web interfaces. CSS-first, accessible by default, three ways to consume.

import { Card, CardGrid, Tabs, TabItem, LinkCard } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"
## What does Paramanu mean? **Paramanu** () is a Sanskrit term meaning **atom** the smallest, indivisible particle of matter. In the ancient Indian Vaisheshika school of philosophy, paramanu represented the fundamental building blocks from which all physical reality is composed. This design system carries the same idea: **the smallest, composable building blocks for crafting web interfaces**. Each token, style, and component is a paramanu minimal, purposeful, and designed to combine into something greater.
## Why Paramanu? Built entirely on CSS custom properties and `@layer` cascade ordering. No JavaScript is needed for styling your buttons, inputs, and layouts work without a framework. Drop in via **CDN** with human-readable classes, use as **CSS Modules** in bundled apps for scoped styles, or import **React components** with full type safety. Every component ships WCAG 2.2 AA compliant. Focus-visible indicators, semantic HTML, `aria` attributes, and automated testing with axe-core accessibility isn't an afterthought. CSS nesting, `light-dark()` for automatic dark mode, `@layer` for predictable cascade, container queries, and `@scope` built for how CSS works today.
## Three Ways to Use Choose the integration that fits your project: Link the stylesheet and start using classes immediately. No build tools needed. ```html ``` Import as CSS Modules for scoped class names in bundled applications. ```js import classes from "@paramanu/buttons-js/modules/button/map" const btn = document.createElement("button") btn.className = classes["pm-button"] + " " + classes["pm-button--primary"] btn.textContent = "Get Started" ``` Import typed React components with full prop autocompletion. ```tsx import { Button } from "@paramanu/buttons-react" export default function App() { return } ```
## Design Principles Every component does one thing well. No bloated bundles, no hidden dependencies, no surprise side effects. Ship only what you use. Tokens feed into components, components combine into patterns. Override any layer without fighting specificity wars. Starts with semantic HTML and CSS. Layer on JavaScript interactivity only when needed. Works without JS, shines with it. Swap design tokens at the root level to re-skin everything. Built-in `light-dark()` support means dark mode with one CSS property.
## Start Building

Using Paramanu with human-readable CSS classes via CDN.

The CDN bundle provides human-readable BEM-like class names. No build step required.

## Setup

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="paramanu.min.css">
<script src="paramanu.min.js"></script>
```

## Button

```html
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--md">
  Click me
</button>
```

### Variants

```html
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--md">Primary</button>
<button class="pm-button pm-button--secondary pm-button--md">Secondary</button>
<button class="pm-button pm-button--danger pm-button--md">Danger</button>
<button class="pm-button pm-button--ghost pm-button--md">Ghost</button>
```

### Sizes

```html
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--sm">Small</button>
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--md">Medium</button>
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--lg">Large</button>
```

### Disabled

```html
<button class="pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--md pm-button--disabled"
        disabled aria-disabled="true">
  Disabled
</button>
```

## Using the JS Helper

The CDN bundle also exposes `window.Paramanu` with class builder functions:

```html
<script>
  const classes = Paramanu.buttonClasses({ variant: 'danger', size: 'lg' })
  // "pm-button pm-button--danger pm-button--lg"
</script>
```
How to install Paramanu in your project.

## Package Manager

Install the group packages you need. Each component group is a separate package:

```bash
# Design tokens (always needed)
pnpm add @paramanu/tokens

# Buttons (JS class builders + CSS)
pnpm add @paramanu/buttons-js

# Buttons (React wrappers, optional)
pnpm add @paramanu/buttons-react
```

Available groups: `primitives`, `typography`, `buttons`, `forms`, `navigation`, `data-display`, `feedback`, `overlays`, `disclosure`, `utilities`.

Each group follows the pattern `@paramanu/<group>-js` and `@paramanu/<group>-react`.

## CDN

For quick prototyping or static sites, use the CDN bundle:

```html
<link rel="stylesheet" href="https://unpkg.com/@paramanu/cdn/dist/paramanu.min.css">
<script src="https://unpkg.com/@paramanu/cdn/dist/paramanu.min.js"></script>
```

## Next Steps

Choose your consumption mode:

- [CDN (human-readable classes)](/getting-started/usage-cdn/)
- [Templated (CSS modules)](/getting-started/usage-templated/)
- [React components](/getting-started/usage-react/)

The React package provides typed, accessible components with `forwardRef` support.

## Setup

```tsx
// Import CSS once at your app root
import "@paramanu/buttons-js/css"
```

## Button

```tsx
import { Button } from "@paramanu/buttons-react"

function App() {
  return (
    <Button variant="primary" size="md" onClick={() => alert("Clicked!")}>
      Click me
    </Button>
  )
}
```

### Props

| Prop | Type | Default | Description |
|---|---|---|---|
| `variant` | `"primary" \| "secondary" \| "danger" \| "ghost"` | `"primary"` | Visual style |
| `size` | `"sm" \| "md" \| "lg"` | `"md"` | Size |
| `disabled` | `boolean` | `false` | Disabled state |
| `fullWidth` | `boolean` | `false` | Full width |
| `type` | `"button" \| "submit" \| "reset"` | `"button"` | HTML button type |

All standard HTML button attributes are also accepted.

### Examples

```tsx
<Button variant="primary">Primary</Button>
<Button variant="secondary">Secondary</Button>
<Button variant="danger">Danger</Button>
<Button variant="ghost">Ghost</Button>
<Button size="sm">Small</Button>
<Button size="lg">Large</Button>
<Button disabled>Disabled</Button>
<Button fullWidth>Full Width</Button>
```
Using Paramanu with CSS modules for hashed class names in bundled apps.

The templated mode uses CSS modules with hashed class names, ideal for bundled applications.

## Setup

```ts
import "@paramanu/buttons-js/css"
```

## Using CSS Modules

```ts
import { buttonModuleClasses } from "@paramanu/buttons-js"
import classMap from "@paramanu/buttons-js/modules/button/map"

const className = buttonModuleClasses(classMap, {
  variant: "primary",
  size: "md",
})
// Returns hashed class names like "pm_a1b2_pm-button pm_c3d4_pm-button--primary ..."
```

## Using Human-Readable Classes

You can also use the readable class builder in any template:

```ts
import { buttonClasses } from "@paramanu/buttons-js"

const className = buttonClasses({ variant: "primary", size: "md" })
// "pm-button pm-button--primary pm-button--md"
```

## Example with a Template Engine

```html
<!-- EJS / Handlebars / Nunjucks -->
<button class="<%= buttonClasses({ variant: 'primary', size: 'md' }) %>">
  Click me
</button>
```

Spacing tokens follow a 4px base grid. Available as CSS custom properties with the `--pm-spacing-` prefix.

## Scale

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-spacing-0` | `0px` |
| `--pm-spacing-1` | `4px` |
| `--pm-spacing-2` | `8px` |
| `--pm-spacing-3` | `12px` |
| `--pm-spacing-4` | `16px` |
| `--pm-spacing-5` | `20px` |
| `--pm-spacing-6` | `24px` |
| `--pm-spacing-8` | `32px` |
| `--pm-spacing-10` | `40px` |
| `--pm-spacing-12` | `48px` |
| `--pm-spacing-16` | `64px` |

## Border Radius

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-radius-none` | `0px` |
| `--pm-radius-sm` | `4px` |
| `--pm-radius-md` | `6px` |
| `--pm-radius-lg` | `8px` |
| `--pm-radius-xl` | `12px` |
| `--pm-radius-full` | `9999px` |

## Usage

```css
.my-element {
  padding: var(--pm-spacing-4);
  margin-bottom: var(--pm-spacing-2);
  border-radius: var(--pm-radius-md);
}
```

Typography tokens cover font families, sizes, weights, and line heights.

## Font Families

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-font-family-sans` | `system-ui, -apple-system, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, ...` |
| `--pm-font-family-mono` | `ui-monospace, 'Cascadia Code', 'Source Code Pro', ...` |

## Font Sizes

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-font-size-xs` | `0.75rem` (12px) |
| `--pm-font-size-sm` | `0.875rem` (14px) |
| `--pm-font-size-md` | `1rem` (16px) |
| `--pm-font-size-lg` | `1.125rem` (18px) |
| `--pm-font-size-xl` | `1.25rem` (20px) |
| `--pm-font-size-2xl` | `1.5rem` (24px) |
| `--pm-font-size-3xl` | `1.875rem` (30px) |

## Font Weights

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-font-weight-normal` | `400` |
| `--pm-font-weight-medium` | `500` |
| `--pm-font-weight-semibold` | `600` |
| `--pm-font-weight-bold` | `700` |

## Line Heights

| Token | Value |
|---|---|
| `--pm-font-lineHeight-tight` | `1.25` |
| `--pm-font-lineHeight-normal` | `1.5` |
| `--pm-font-lineHeight-relaxed` | `1.75` |

## Usage

```css
.my-heading {
  font-family: var(--pm-font-family-sans);
  font-size: var(--pm-font-size-2xl);
  font-weight: var(--pm-font-weight-bold);
  line-height: var(--pm-font-lineHeight-tight);
}
```
